title: How to Change Keyboard Layout in Ubuntu

steps.title: Open your Ubuntu Settings.
steps.content: Open your Ubuntu Settings. To do this, click the small down-arrow at the top-right corner of the desktop, and then click the icon of a wrench and a screwdriver. You can also get there by opening the Activities overview and clicking Settings . [2] X Research source

steps.title: Click the Region and Language tab.
steps.content: Click the Region and Language tab. It's in the left panel. Your language and input settings will open in the right panel.

steps.title: Click the + under "Input Sources."
steps.content: Click the + under "Input Sources." This opens a list of languages.

steps.title: Click a layout once to select it.
steps.content: Click a layout once to select it. If you don't see the desired language, click the three vertical dots below the list to expand more options. If you still don't see it, click Other to display even more languages. [3] X Research source If you still don't see the layout you're looking for, close the window and press Ctrl + T to open a terminal window. Run the command settings set org.gnome.desktop.input-sources show-all-sources true and then return to the Region and Language tab to try again. [4] X Research source Depending on the language, you may have more than one layout from which to choose. For example, for English, you'll see English (US), English (Australia), English (Canada), English (United Kingdom), etc. Another example is for Cameroonâ€”you'll find Cameroon Multilingual (Dvorak) and Cameroon Multilingual (QWERTY).

steps.title: Click the Add button.
steps.content: Click the Add button. It appears at the top-right corner once you select a layout. This adds the layout to the Input Sources list.

steps.title: Move the default layout to the top of the list.
steps.content: Move the default layout to the top of the list. The first layout in the Input Sources section is the layout Ubuntu associates with your keyboard by default. If you'd like to choose a different default layout, select the layout, and then click the up-arrow (^) button below the list until it's at the top. If you want to assign different layouts for certain windows (ex: You're writing in Spanish for one project, and English in another), click the Options button above the input list to view your settings for multiple inputs. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Switch between layouts.
steps.content: Switch between layouts. When you have more than one keyboard layout in your list of Input Sources, a keyboard menu appears at the top-right corner of the screen. It'll be a small downward-pointing arrow with the first few letters of the language beside it. To switch between layouts, click this menu, and then choose another layout.
